options.text: It assumes that air streams meet at the trailing edge.

options.label: B
options.text: It assumes that air above the wing goes slower.

options.label: C
options.text: It assumes that the wing deflects air downwards.

options.label: D
options.text: It assumes that the angle of attack is not important.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the deflection of air and the lift generated lift?

options.label: A
options.text: The deflection of air creates a pressure difference that generates lift.

options.label: B
options.text: The deflection of air does not create a pressure difference that generates lift.

options.label: C
options.text: The deflection of air creates a pressure difference that does not generate lift.

options.label: D
options.text: The deflection of air does not create a pressure difference.

multiple-choice.question: According to the video, what is the correct explanation for the lift generated by a wing?

options.label: B
options.text: The air streams meet at the trailing edge.

options.label: C
options.text: The pressure difference created by air traveling faster over the top of the wing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the coanda effect in the lift generated by a wing?

options.label: A
options.text: It guides air above the wing along its surface and down.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no role in the lift generated by a wing.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the Bernoulli explanation not entirely wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: It assumes that air streams meet at the trailing edge.

options.label: B
options.text: It assumes that the wing deflects air downwards.

options.label: C
options.text: It explains the pressure difference created by air traveling faster over the top of the wing.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no relevance to the lift generated by a wing.

multiple-choice.question: According to the video, what is the relationship between the simplified explanation and the more accurate explanation?

options.label: A
options.text: They are two different explanations for the same phenomenon.

options.label: B
options.text: They are two explanations that contradict each other.

options.label: C
options.text: They are two explanations that are not relevant to the lift generated by a wing.

options.label: D
options.text: They are two explanations that are not accurate.

title: How does digestion work?

options.label: C

title: Gerrymandering: How drawing jagged lines can impact an election - Christina Greer

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the term "gerrymandering"?

options.label: A
options.text: It comes from the name of a famous politician who practiced gerrymandering.

options.label: B
options.text: It was coined by a journalist who described the new district lines as resembling a salamander.

options.label: C
options.text: It is an acronym for the name of a political party.

options.label: D
options.text: It was derived from a word that means "redistricting".

multiple-choice.question: What was the main goal of Elbridge Gerry when he redrew district lines in 1812?

options.label: B
options.text: To favor his own political party.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the number of districts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process of packing a district?

options.label: A
options.text: Breaking up a voting bloc by spreading their supporters across multiple districts.

options.label: B
options.text: Drawing district lines to pack opponents into as few districts as possible.

options.label: C
options.text: Diluting opponents' voters by packing them into one district.

options.label: D
options.text: Increasing voter turnout by creating more districts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the opposite of packing a district?
Why do parties choose to pack or crack districts?

options.label: B
options.text: To favor their own political party.

options.label: C
options.text: To dilute opponents' voters or spread their own supporters across multiple districts.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the number of districts.

multiple-choice.question: What is a voting bloc?

options.label: A
options.text: A group of people who support a particular party.

options.label: B
options.text: A group of people who live in a particular district.

options.label: C
options.text: A group of people who are packed into a single district.

options.label: D
options.text: A group of people who are spread across multiple districts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between packing and cracking a district?

options.label: A
options.text: Packing involves spreading supporters across multiple districts, while cracking involves packing them into a single district.

options.label: B
options.text: Packing involves packing opponents into a single district, while cracking involves spreading them across multiple districts.

options.label: C
options.text: Packing involves increasing voter turnout, while cracking involves decreasing voter turnout.

options.label: D
options.text: Packing involves creating more competitive districts, while cracking involves creating less competitive districts.

multiple-choice.question: Why is gerrymandering a relevant issue in politics today?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is an outdated practice.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a necessary practice.

options.label: C
options.text: Because politicians often use creative methods to redraw district lines and gain an advantage over their opponents.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a practice that is only used in certain states.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term "gerrymandering" derived from?

options.label: A
options.text: The name of a famous politician.

options.label: B
options.text: The name of a political party.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of gerrymandering?

options.label: B
options.text: To favor one political party over another.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the number of districts.

options.label: B

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What type of behaviors are associated with abnormalities in the amygdala?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It is a comparison between the zombie cat and Patient H.M.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a metaphor for the complexities of emotions and behavior

options.label: D
options.text: It is a scientific explanation for the Papez circuit

options.label: A
options.text: To discuss the neural basis of emotions and behavior

options.label: B

options.label: D
